Once I have it written down, I can read it out loud a few times, just to get used to saying it. I could even set a reminder on my phone for later today to check in with myself and repeat it again when I start to feel that anxiety bubbling up. Just taking that first step might help me feel a bit more grounded. But, I still worry that when the time comes, I’ll forget all of this and just get overwhelmed again. It's frustrating to feel this way, but I guess I have to keep trying, right?

I think connecting with that mantra and reminding myself of my strengths could feel really empowering. Writing it down in a way that feels special might help me internalize it more, like I’m really committing to this process. When I read it aloud, I can almost picture myself in that moment with my dad, trying to talk about my feelings. It could serve as a little anchor for me, a way to ground myself when the anxiety starts creeping in. I guess I’m hoping it brings a sense of calm and reassurance, even if just for a moment. But, there’s still that nagging doubt that I might not be able to hold onto that feeling when the time comes. It’s frustrating because I want to believe in my ability to do this, but that fear is always lurking. I know I have to keep pushing through, though. It’s just... tough sometimes.

full_conversation.content: Hi Blaise, it's good to see you today. What brings you to therapy at this time?

I guess I just... I don't know. I feel like I'm stuck in this loop with my family, especially with my dad. There's been this whole thing about my wedding list, and it just brings up so many feelings. I keep thinking about how I want his approval, but at the same time, I feel like I’m constantly chasing something that might not even be there. It’s frustrating. I mean, I want to talk about it, but I also feel overwhelmed. It just gets... complicated.

It sounds like you're feeling a lot of pressure around your father's approval, which is leading to frustration and overwhelm. Let’s try to map this out a bit. When you think, "I need my dad's approval," you feel anxious and frustrated, and then you might find yourself either trying to please him or withdrawing. Which part of this triangle feels most changeable for you right now?

I don't know, it just feels like everything is tangled together. I mean, the anxiety is there, and it drives me to either try harder or just shut down completely. But honestly, I’m not even sure if I can change how I feel about needing his approval. It feels like this constant cycle, and every time I think I can break free, something pulls me back in. It’s like I’m stuck between wanting to voice my thoughts and being scared of what might happen if I do. I don’t want to create more conflict, but at the same time, I feel like I’m losing myself. Do you really think there’s a way to change this?

It seems like you're caught in a really tough place, wanting to express yourself while also fearing the potential fallout from that. It sounds like there's a part of you that longs for authenticity and connection, but another part is worried about the conflict that might arise from voicing your true feelings. That must be really challenging, feeling like you're losing yourself in the process. Did I get that right?

Yeah, you got that right. It’s just… I want to be honest with him, but then I think about how he might react, and it makes me hesitate. I mean, it feels like I’m just walking on eggshells all the time, trying to keep the peace. I keep telling myself that maybe if I just keep quiet or go along with what he wants, things will be easier. But then I end up feeling resentful and trapped. It’s like I’m stuck in this cycle of wanting to be free but also needing to feel accepted. I guess I just don’t know how to break that cycle without it blowing up in my face.

It sounds like you're navigating a delicate balance between the desire for acceptance and the need for your own voice, which can feel incredibly frustrating. I can sense how much you want to break free from this cycle, yet the fear of conflict holds you back. What do you think would happen if you were to express your true feelings to your dad?

I think... if I were to actually express my true feelings, it could go one of two ways. On one hand, he might actually listen and understand, and that would feel amazing. But then, there's this other side of me that’s convinced he’d react negatively, maybe even get angry or dismissive. I mean, it's happened before. I just can't shake the fear that it might push him away or cause a rift. And that thought is really scary because, at the end of the day, I don’t want to lose him. It’s just this constant battle in my head, you know? I want to be honest, but the potential fallout makes me freeze up. So, I end up just holding it all in, which only makes things worse. I just... I don’t know how to navigate that.

It sounds like you're feeling torn between the hope that your dad might respond positively and the fear of a negative reaction that could push him away. That internal conflict seems to create a lot of tension for you, as you want to be honest but feel paralyzed by the potential consequences. It must be incredibly difficult to hold all of that in, knowing it could lead to resentment. How do you think you might start to explore this balance between honesty and your fear of conflict?

I mean, exploring that balance feels daunting. Part of me thinks maybe I could start small, like just sharing little things that don’t feel as risky. But then I wonder if that’s just delaying the inevitable. I keep thinking about how I’ve tried to voice my feelings before, and it didn’t go well, so why would it be different this time? I guess I’m just really hesitant. It’s like, what if I try to open up, and it all backfires? I don't want to create more distance or make things worse than they already are. But I also don't want to keep bottling everything up—it just feels like I’m suffocating. It’s just hard to see a clear path, you know? I’m stuck between wanting to speak up and the fear of being shut down again.

It sounds like you're feeling really overwhelmed by the idea of opening up, especially given past experiences that didn’t go well. That hesitation is completely understandable, considering the stakes involved with your relationship with your dad. Before we dive deeper into this, would it help to take a moment to acknowledge what you're feeling right now? Maybe we could take a slow breath together and name those feelings, just to steady things a bit. Would you like to try that?

I mean, I guess we could try that. It feels a bit strange to just pause and name my feelings, but maybe it could help. Right now, I’m feeling a mix of anxiety and tension, like there’s this knot in my stomach. I keep thinking about everything I’ve shared and how complicated it all feels. I feel worried about what could happen if I really open up, but at the same time, there’s this underlying desire to just be honest. It’s just... a lot, you know? Taking a moment to breathe and acknowledge that might help me sort through some of it, I suppose.

I hear you, Blaise. You're feeling a mix of anxiety and tension, and there's a real struggle between wanting to be honest and the fear of what that honesty might bring. It’s understandable to feel that knot in your stomach when you’re navigating such complicated emotions. Taking a moment to breathe and acknowledge those feelings can be a helpful step in sorting through everything. Where would you like to focus next—exploring those feelings further or discussing how to approach the conversation with your dad?

I think... I’m not sure. Part of me wants to explore these feelings more because they seem to be at the core of everything. But then, there's this other part that feels like we should just jump into how to approach my dad because that feels more practical. It’s just that I worry if I don’t fully understand these feelings, I might just end up in the same place again. It’s like I need to untangle this mess before I can really think about what to say to him. But then again, what if I get stuck in this loop of overthinking? I guess I’m just feeling really torn about it all. Maybe starting with the feelings would help, but I’m also hesitant to dive too deep. It’s complicated, you know?

It sounds like you're feeling quite torn between wanting to explore your feelings and the practical need to address the situation with your dad. It's completely valid to want to understand those emotions better before taking action, especially given how complex they are. How about we take a moment to identify one specific feeling that stands out to you right now? From there, we can decide if you want to unpack that feeling further or think about how it might influence your approach with your dad. What do you think?

I guess if I had to pick one feeling that stands out, it would be anxiety. It’s like this constant background noise in my head, always reminding me of the potential fallout if I were to actually say what I’m feeling. I can feel my heart racing just thinking about it. It’s frustrating because I want to be able to express myself without feeling this weight pressing down on me. But then I get caught up in the "what ifs"—what if he reacts poorly? What if it leads to an argument? It just makes me second-guess everything. I don’t know if I’ll ever feel completely ready to face that anxiety. It’s just hard to envision a way through it.

It sounds like anxiety is really taking center stage for you, creating that constant pressure and making it difficult to envision a way forward. It’s understandable to feel overwhelmed by all the "what ifs" when thinking about expressing yourself. Would you be open to trying a small step to test this anxiety? For instance, what if you replied to your dad with a ‘maybe’ about a family event and asked one practical question related to it? This could give you a chance to gauge his response without diving into the deeper feelings just yet. How does that sound to you?

I mean, that sounds like it could be a way to ease into things without jumping in headfirst. It’s definitely less risky than laying everything out there all at once. But I still feel that knot in my stomach just thinking about it. What if he takes it the wrong way or gets annoyed? It’s like I want to try this, but there's this fear that creeps in, telling me it won’t go well. I guess testing the waters could help me gauge his reaction, but I can’t help but feel like I’m still tiptoeing around the bigger issue, you know? It’s frustrating to feel stuck between wanting to take a step forward and the fear of what might happen. I want to believe it could work, but... it’s hard to shake that anxiety.

It seems like you’re feeling a lot of tension around the idea of taking that small step, especially with the anxiety creeping in about how your dad might react. It’s understandable to feel frustrated when you want to move forward but are held back by fear. What do you think would help you feel a bit more at ease as you consider this approach?

I think... maybe if I could find a way to remind myself that it’s just a small step and not the end of the world, it might help ease that tension a bit. I mean, it’s not like I’m laying everything out there right away. I guess I could try reframing it in my head, telling myself that it’s just a way to test the waters and not a definitive statement about my feelings. But there's still that nagging worry about how he might take it. If I could just feel a bit more grounded before approaching him, maybe I wouldn’t feel so anxious. It’s just hard to shake off that feeling of impending doom when it comes to these conversations. I need to find something to hold onto that reminds me this doesn’t have to be so heavy.

It sounds like you're recognizing the importance of reframing this step as a way to test the waters rather than a definitive declaration of your feelings. That shift in perspective could help alleviate some of the heaviness you're feeling. It's completely normal to have that nagging worry about how your dad might react, especially given the history you have. Finding something to ground yourself in before approaching him could be really beneficial. What kind of reminders or affirmations do you think might help you feel more anchored as you prepare for this conversation?

I guess I could think about some affirmations that remind me it’s okay to express my feelings, even if they’re small steps. Something like, “It’s okay to feel anxious, but taking this step doesn’t define our whole relationship.” Or maybe, “Trying to communicate is a sign of strength, not weakness.” I feel like having those phrases in my mind could help me calm down a bit before I talk to him. But then, I wonder if I’ll actually remember them in the moment. It’s like I need to practice saying them to myself more often so they stick. I just hope that when the time comes, I can hold onto that grounding feeling instead of letting the anxiety take over. It’s tough to picture that happening, though. I mean, what if I just freeze up again?

It sounds like you're beginning to identify some affirmations that resonate with you, which could serve as helpful reminders to ease your anxiety when you approach your dad. It's understandable to worry about whether you'll remember them in the moment, especially when anxiety can feel so overwhelming. Practicing those phrases regularly could help reinforce them in your mind, making it easier to draw on them when you need them most. What do you think might be a good way to incorporate that practice into your routine before the conversation?

I think it might be helpful to set aside a few minutes each day to repeat those affirmations to myself, maybe when I first wake up or right before I go to bed. That way, I can create a little routine around it. I could even write them down and put them somewhere I can see them, like on my bathroom mirror or my fridge. I guess having those visual reminders could help reinforce them in my mind. But then I worry, what if I still feel too anxious in the moment to remember them? I just want to make sure I’m prepared, but it feels like there’s always that uncertainty hanging over me. It’s just... hard to feel confident about it all.

It sounds like you’re coming up with some practical strategies to incorporate those affirmations into your daily routine, which is a great step toward feeling more prepared. Writing them down and placing them in visible spots can definitely reinforce their presence in your mind. It’s completely normal to still feel anxious about remembering them in the moment, especially given the stakes involved. One idea might be to practice saying them aloud during moments of calm, so they become more familiar to you. How does that feel to you, and is there a specific affirmation you’d like to focus on as you prepare for this conversation with your dad?

I think practicing them aloud could really help make them feel more natural. If I can get used to saying them when I’m calm, maybe it’ll be easier to recall them when I’m actually in the moment with my dad. As for a specific affirmation, I think I’d like to focus on, “Trying to communicate is a sign of strength, not weakness.” That one resonates a lot because it shifts my perspective on what it means to express myself. I just hope that when the time comes, I can hold onto that feeling of strength instead of letting the anxiety cloud my mind. But, I guess I still feel that nagging worry that no matter how much I prepare, I might still end up freezing up. It’s just hard to shake off that uncertainty.

It sounds like you're finding value in the affirmation, “Trying to communicate is a sign of strength, not weakness,” and that it resonates with your desire to express yourself. Practicing it aloud during calmer moments can definitely help make it feel more natural when the time comes. It's completely understandable to still feel that nagging worry about freezing up, especially given the uncertainty of how your dad might react. As you prepare, what do you think could help you manage that uncertainty and remind yourself that it’s okay to take this step, even if it feels daunting?

I guess reminding myself that it’s okay to feel uncertain could be helpful. I mean, it’s a part of the process, right? Maybe I could think about how every step I take, even the small ones, is a move towards being more authentic. I could acknowledge that it’s normal to feel anxious about these conversations, especially since they mean so much to me. I could also try to be kinder to myself in those moments, telling myself that it’s okay to not have everything figured out. I just keep worrying about whether I'll actually be able to follow through when the time comes. It feels like there’s this pressure to get it right, but I know that every attempt is a step forward, even if it doesn’t go perfectly. I just need to find a way to hold onto that mindset when I’m actually facing my dad. It's just... so tough to shake off the fear.

You're recognizing that it's okay to feel uncertain and that acknowledging those feelings is part of the process. That’s a significant insight, Blaise. It shows a lot of strength to remind yourself that every small step you take is a move toward being more authentic, even when the pressure feels overwhelming. Being kinder to yourself in those moments can really help ease that burden. It’s clear you’re committed to this journey, and that commitment itself is a testament to your resilience. As you prepare to face your dad, what might be one way you can practice that self-compassion in the moment?

I think one way I could practice self-compassion in the moment is by giving myself permission to feel whatever comes up, whether it’s anxiety, fear, or even relief. I could remind myself that it’s okay if things don’t go perfectly—what matters is that I’m trying to express myself and be authentic. Maybe I could take a deep breath before speaking, just to center myself and acknowledge that it’s a tough situation. I could tell myself that I’m doing my best and that it’s natural to feel nervous. It’s just hard to imagine being that gentle with myself when I’m actually facing my dad. I keep worrying I might just revert back to old patterns and freeze up. It feels like I need to find a way to trust that I can handle whatever comes my way, but that’s easier said than done.

You’re highlighting some really important strategies for practicing self-compassion, like giving yourself permission to feel whatever arises and reminding yourself that it’s okay if things don’t go perfectly. Taking a deep breath before speaking is a great way to center yourself and create a moment of calm amidst the anxiety. It’s understandable to worry about reverting to old patterns, especially in such a significant situation. What do you think could help you build that trust in yourself, so you feel more confident in handling whatever comes your way during your conversation with your dad?

I think building that trust in myself might come from recognizing the progress I've made so far, even if it feels small. I could remind myself of the times I did manage to express my feelings, even if the outcomes weren't perfect. Maybe I could keep a journal to reflect on those moments and the strength it took to share my thoughts, which could help reinforce that confidence. I guess it’s about acknowledging that each attempt, regardless of the result, is a step toward being more authentic. But still, there’s this lingering fear that when the time comes, all that progress could just fade away in the face of my dad’s reaction. It feels like I need to find a way to ground myself in those past experiences while also accepting that I might feel anxious. It’s just... tough to strike that balance.

You're recognizing the importance of acknowledging your progress and the strength it takes to express your feelings, which is a powerful step toward building trust in yourself. Keeping a journal to reflect on those moments can serve as a valuable reminder of your resilience and growth. It’s completely normal to feel that lingering fear about how your dad might react, especially when emotions run high. As you prepare for this conversation, what might be one specific way you can draw on those past experiences to help ground you in the moment, even if anxiety arises?

I think one specific way I could draw on those past experiences is by taking a moment before the conversation to recall a time when I did express myself, even if it went differently than I hoped. I could remind myself of how I felt afterward, like the relief of having shared my thoughts, regardless of the outcome. Maybe I could create a little mental checklist of those moments, so when I start to feel anxious, I can just pause and remember that I have faced tough conversations before. This could help me feel more grounded, even if the anxiety is still there. It’s just... I worry that in the heat of the moment, I'll forget all that and just focus on the fear instead. I guess I need to find a way to keep those positive memories close, especially when I’m facing my dad. It just feels like an uphill battle sometimes.

You’re identifying a really effective strategy by recalling past experiences where you successfully expressed yourself, even if the outcomes weren't what you hoped for. I think I could start by writing down a couple of those positive memories in my journal, maybe even detailing how I felt afterward. I could revisit them regularly, especially in the days leading up to the conversation with my dad. Having them written down might make it easier to recall them when anxiety kicks in. I could also think about how those moments felt empowering, reminding myself that I can handle tough situations, even if they don't go perfectly. I guess I could even practice visualizing those memories, like a little mental rehearsal, so they stick with me better. But still, there's this nagging thought that when the moment comes, I might just freeze and forget everything. It's frustrating to feel so prepared in theory but still worry about the execution when it really matters. I just hope I can hold onto that sense of strength when I need it most.

You’re really honing in on some practical ways to incorporate those positive memories into your preparation, which can help reinforce your sense of strength. Writing them down and revisiting them regularly is a great strategy, and visualizing those moments can create a more vivid connection to your past successes. It’s completely natural to feel that nagging worry about freezing up in the moment, especially when the stakes feel high. I think creating a sense of safety for myself could come from establishing a few grounding rituals before the conversation. Maybe I could find a quiet space to take a few deep breaths and remind myself of those affirmations, like “Trying to communicate is a sign of strength, not weakness.” I could also set the intention that it's okay to feel anxious and that I don’t have to get it all right in that moment. Having a plan for what I want to say could help too, just to give me a bit of structure to hold onto when things get overwhelming. I guess being gentle with myself and allowing for the possibility of discomfort could create a safe space, even if it’s just in my own mind. Still, I can’t shake the worry that when it’s time to actually talk to him, I’ll just lock up again. It feels like I need to find a way to trust that I can navigate through this, but it’s hard to silence that fear.

You’re identifying some really thoughtful ways to create a sense of safety for yourself, like establishing grounding rituals and setting intentions for the conversation. Trusting in your ability to navigate through this is a process, and it’s okay to acknowledge that fear while also holding space for your strengths. What do you think might help you balance that fear with the confidence you’re building as you approach this conversation?

I think balancing that fear with the confidence I'm trying to build could come from reminding myself that it’s okay to feel both emotions at the same time. I mean, I can be anxious and still take steps forward. Maybe I could focus on celebrating the small victories, like just getting through the conversation itself, regardless of the outcome. Every time I acknowledge that I faced my fear, I’d reinforce that confidence a little more. I could also remind myself that it’s normal to feel a bit shaky before having tough talks, and that doesn’t mean I can’t handle it. But, there’s still this voice in my head that tells me it might not go well, and it’s frustrating to feel like I have to fight against that. I guess I need to keep working on trusting that I have the tools and strategies to manage whatever happens, even if it feels daunting. It’s just... tough to shake off the fear that keeps creeping back in.

You’re really capturing the essence of balancing both fear and confidence, recognizing that it’s okay to feel anxious while still moving forward. Celebrating those small victories, like simply getting through the conversation, can be a powerful way to reinforce your confidence over time. It’s completely normal for that voice of doubt to surface, especially when facing something significant. I think one specific small victory I can set my sights on is just initiating the conversation with my dad, whether it’s bringing up my feelings or even just testing the waters with a lighter topic. Acknowledging that I took that step, no matter how it goes, could be really important. Afterward, I could reward myself in some small way, like treating myself to something I enjoy or taking a moment to reflect in my journal about how I felt during the conversation. I just hope I can keep that perspective when I’m in the moment, but I know it’s a process. It’s just hard to shake that feeling of doubt that lingers.

You’re identifying a meaningful small victory by focusing on initiating the conversation with your dad, which is a significant step in itself. Acknowledging that effort, regardless of the outcome, can really help reinforce your progress and commitment to expressing yourself. As you prepare for this conversation, what might help you remind yourself to hold onto that perspective, especially when those feelings of doubt arise?

I think one way to remind myself to hold onto that perspective is by creating a little mantra or reminder that I can refer to when those doubts creep in.
